title: Porous Silicon Microparticles for Delivery of siRNA Therapeutics
procedures:
1. PCPS Particle Preparation
Oxidize non-functionalized porous silicon particles in a 30% solution of hydrogen peroxide at 95 °C for 2 hr. Aminate the oxidized particles in 2% (3-​aminopropyl)​triethoxysilane solution in isopropyl alcohol for 2 days at 65 °C with gentle stirring.
Centrifuge the solution for 30 min at 18,800 x g and wash the particles twice in isopropyl alcohol and three times in ethanol, using brief sonication to suspend the pellet. Leave the particles in ethanol solution when performing step 1.3 and 1.4.
Add a known volume of particle suspension (e.g., 10 μl) to 10 ml isotone diluent and count the particles with a particle counting analyzer to determine the concentration of particles in the stock solution.
Activate the acid group of L-arginine (0.1 nmol) with N-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)-N′-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC, 0.1 nmol)/N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS, 0.1 nmol) in 20 ml of ethanol for 2 hr at RT with gentle stirring.
Briefly sonicate the particle stock solution and add 1 billion particles to the L-arginine solution and leave the reaction for 18 hr at RT with gentle stirring.
Activate the first aspartic acid group of N-(tert-Butoxycarbonyl)-L-aspartic acid (Boc-Asp-OH, 1 nmol) with EDC (0.1 nmol)/NHS (0.1 nmol) in 20 ml of ethanol for 4 hr at 4 °C with gentle stirring.
Dissolve 50 mg polyethylenimine in 10 ml ethanol and add the solution to the Boc-Asp-OH mixture. Let the reaction proceed for 24 hr at RT with gentle stirring.
Activate the second aspartic acid group of the Boc-Asp-OH/PEI solution with EDC (0.1 nmol)/NHS (0.1 nmol) at 4 °C for 6 hr with gentle stirring.
To obtain PCPS particles, add the particle solution from step 1.5 into the Boc-Asp-OH/PEI solution from step 1.8. Allow the reaction to proceed for 18 hr at RT with gentle stirring.

Centrifuge the solution for 30 min at 18,800 x g and wash the particle solution three times with ethanol, using brief sonication to suspend the pellet.
2. PCPS Particle Characterization
Measure the size of the particles using a scanning electron microscope (SEM).
	
Place a drop of particle suspension (10,000 particles/μl in ethanol) on a clean silica SEM sample stub and let dry at RT under vacuum.
Measure SEM images at 8 kV with a 3–5 mm working distance using an in-lens detector.
Measure the zeta potential of the particles using a particle analyzer system.
	
Mix 10 μl of particle suspension (10,000 particles/μl in ethanol) with 1 ml of 10 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
Load the sample into folded capillary cells and measure the zeta potential according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
3. Loading of siRNA into PCPS Particles
Dry the PCPS particles (from PCPS particle preparation step 1.9) under vacuum O/N.
Add siRNA (4 μg) in nuclease-free water (20 μl) to the dried PCPS particles and sonicate briefly. Use the following particle to siRNA ratios: 2 × 105 particles/0.2 μg siRNA, 4 × 105 particles/0.2 μg siRNA, 6 × 105 particles/0.2 μg siRNA, 8 × 105 particles/0.2 μg siRNA, 10 × 105 particles/0.2 μg siRNA and 12 × 105 particles/0.2 μg siRNA.
Incubate for 3 hr at 4 °C on a shaker (1,000 rpm) to allow siRNA binding to the particles.
4. Optimization of siRNA/PCPS Particle Ratio
Add DNA loading dye to 20 μl of the PCPS/control siRNA particles with different particle to siRNA ratios (see loading of siRNA into PCPS particles).
Load the samples into a 2% agarose gel containing DNA gel stain.
Perform electrophoresis at a constant voltage of 120 V for 20 min in running buffer.
Analyze the gel with image acquisition and analysis software.

5. Release of siRNA from PCPS Particles
Mix 20 μl of the PCPS/control siRNA particles with different particle to siRNA ratios (see step 3) in sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS, 2%) and let stand for 1 hr at RT.
Add DNA loading dye to the samples.
Load samples into a 2% agarose gel containing DNA gel stain.
Perform electrophoresis at a constant voltage of 120 V for 20 min in running buffer using DNA electrophoresis equipment and a power supply.
Analyze the gel with image acquisition and analysis software.
6. Confocal Microscopy of PCPS Particles
Add 5 μl of PCPS/fluorescent control siRNA particles (10 × 105 particles/0.2 μg siRNA/20 μl) to a glass cover slip.
Visualize particle layers by confocal microscopy.
7. Characterization of Arg-PEI/control siRNA Nanoparticles
To degrade the silicon material and form Arg-PEI/control siRNA nanoparticles, add PCPS/siRNA particles (10 × 106 PCPS particles/2 μg siRNA) to 100 μl of phosphate buffered saline and shake (1,000 rpm) at 37 °C for 2 days.
Centrifuge the sample for 30 min at 18,800 x g and collect the supernatant.
Measure the size of the formed Arg-PEI/siRNA nanoparticles with dynamic light scattering (DLS).
	
Mix 10 μl of the supernatant with 1 ml 10 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) and place into a plastic cuvette.
Measure the size of the particles using a particle analyzer system according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
Determine the size and morphology of the formed Arg/PEI-siRNA nanoparticles with atomic force microscopy.
	
Take 10 µl of the supernatant and place on a silicon wafer.
Visualize the particles with atomic force microscopy (AFM).
8. Cell Culture
Culture MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells in cell culture media supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum and 1% penicillin-streptomycin at 5% CO2, 95% humidity and 37 °C.
9. Confocal Microscopy of Live Cells with PCPS Particles

Plate cells in 2-well culture slides at a seeding density of 3 x 105 cells/well for 24 hr.
Add PCPS particles loaded with fluorescent control siRNA (10 × 105 particles/0.2 μg particle to siRNA ratio, 50 nM siRNA) to cells.
Record a movie of the cells with a confocal microscope (supplied with a chamber, 5% CO2, 95% humidity and 37 °C) for 12 hr following particle exposure.
10. Confocal Microscopy of Fixed Cells with PCPS Particles
Plate cells in 2-well culture slides at a seeding density of 3 x 105 cells/well for 24 hr.
Add PCPS particles loaded with fluorescent control siRNA (10 × 105 particles/0.2 μg particle to siRNA ratio, 50 nM siRNA) to cells and incubate for 1 day, 7 days and 10 days.
Wash the cells twice with phosphate buffered saline and then fix them with 4% paraformaldehyde solution for 10 min.
Wash the cells with phosphate buffered saline.
Permeabilize the cells with 0.1% octyl phenol ethoxylate for 10 min and then wash them three times with phosphate buffered saline.
Block the cells with albumin from bovine serum (10 mg/ml) in phosphate buffered saline for 10 min at RT with gentle stirring.
To visualize filamentous actin, incubate the cells with fluorescently labeled phalloidin (1 μl/40 μl blocking solution) for 20 min at RT with gentle stirring and then wash in phosphate buffered saline.
Remove the slides from the frame and add antifade reagent with 4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) to visualize the nucleus.
Add a cover glass on top and take images of the cells with confocal microscopy.
11. Flow Cytometry of Cells with PCPS/fluorescent Control siRNA Particles
Plate cells in a 6-well plate at a seeding density of 3 x 105 cells/well for 24 hr.

Add PCPS particles loaded with fluorescent control siRNA (10 × 105 particles/0.2 μg particle to siRNA ratio, 50 nM siRNA) to the cells and incubate for 24 hr.
Wash the cells with phosphate buffered saline and scrape them with a cell scraper.
Store the cells in phosphate buffered saline with 2% fetal bovine serum prior to analysis. Use untreated cells as a negative control.
Perform flow cytometry.
12. Cell Viability of Cells with PCPS Particles and PCPS/control siRNA Particles
Plate cells in a 96-well plate at a cell density of 3 × 103 cells/well for 24 hr.
Treat the cells with PCPS particles (1.5 × 105/well and 6 × 105/well) or PCPS/control siRNA particles (10 × 105 particles/0.2 μg particle to siRNA ratio, 10 nM and 100 nM siRNA) for 48 hr and 72 hr. Use untreated cells and cells treated with phosphate buffered saline (same volume as the added particles) as controls. Assay each sample in triplicate.
Perform a cell proliferation assay according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
Represent data as the mean ± standard deviation.
13. Western Blot of Cells with PCPS/ATM Mutated siRNA Particles
Plate cells in a 6-well plate at a cell density 2 × 105 cells/well for 24 hr.
Incubate the cells with PCPS/control siRNA (50 nM) particles or PCPS/ATM siRNA (50 nM) particles for 72 hr. Use untreated cells as a control.
Lyse the cells using a protein extraction reagent supplemented with a protease inhibitor cocktail.
Centrifuge the cell lysates for 10 min at 14,000 x g and recover the supernatant.
Determine the protein concentration with a protein quantification assay according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
Add sample loading buffer (with 5 μl 2-mercaptoethanol/ml buffer) to the samples and heat them for 6 min at 99 °C.

Load the protein samples (20 μg/μl) in a 12% SDS-polyacrylamide gel in running buffer and perform polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (1 hr, 120 V) using electrophoresis equipment and a power supply.
Transfer the gel in transfer buffer (with 20% methanol) to a nitrocellulose membrane (1 hr, 100 V) using electrophoresis equipment and a power supply.
Block the membrane with 5% dry milk for 1 hr.
Incubate the membrane with the ATM primary antibody (from rabbit) in blocking solution (from step 13.9) at a 1:1,000 dilution O/N.
Wash the membrane with phosphate buffered saline containing 0.1% polyethylene glycol sorbitan monolaurate and then incubate it with the secondary antibody (anti-rabbit) in blocking solution (from step 13.9) at a 1:2,500 dilution for 1 hr.
Wash the membrane with phosphate buffered saline containing 0.1% polyethylene glycol sorbitan monolaurate and detect the protein bands with Western blot detection reagent using image acquisition and analysis software.
For the loading control, wash the membrane and repeat steps 13.9-13.12 using a β-actin primary antibody (from mouse, 1:10,000 dilution) and a secondary antibody (anti-mouse 1:4,000 dilution).
